question.content:
Jane earns money walking dogs on the weekends. Jane charges $\$5$ for each dog she walks.

**Complete the table for the given ratio.** 
  
Dogs, $x$ | Charge in dollars, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $5$
$3$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$5$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

**Plot the ordered pairs $(x,y)$ from the table on the following graph.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Jane works at a rate of $\$\blueE5$ for every $\purpleE1$ dog.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

Then we will plot the ratios in the form (dogs, dollars).

If Jane walks $3$ times as many dogs, she earns $3$ times as much money.

|||
-|-|-|-
Dogs | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$
Charge (dollars) | $\blueE{5}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$  | $15$

If Jane walks $5$ times as many dogs, she earns $5$ times as much money.

|||
-|-|-|-
Dogs | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{5}}\rightarrow$ | $5$
Charge (dollars) | $\blueE{5}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{5}}\rightarrow$  | $25$

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Dogs, $x$ | Charge in dollars, $y$ | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ |  $5$ | $(1,5)$
$3$|  $15$ | $(3,15)$
$5$ |  $25$ | $(5,25)$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Dogs and the y-axis labeled Dollars. The points (1, 5), (3, 15), and (5, 25) are plotted.

hints.content:
The completed table

Dogs, $x$ | Charge in dollars, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $5$
$3$|  $15$
$5$ |  $25$

And the completed graph

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Dogs and the y-axis labeled Dollars. The points (1, 5), (3, 15), and (5, 25) are plotted.

question.content:
Callan goes for a hike every Saturday. Callan hikes at a rate of  $6$ kilometers per hour.

**Complete the table for the given ratio.** 
  
Hours, $x$ | Kilometers, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $6$
$3$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$4$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

**Plot the ordered pairs $(x,y)$ from the table on the following graph.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Callan hikes at a rate of $\blueE{6}$ kilometers for every $\purpleE1$ hour.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

Then we will plot the ratios in the form (hours, kilometers).

If Callan hikes $3$ times as many hours, he hikes $3$ times as many kilometers.

|||
-|-|-|-
Hours | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$
Kilometers | $\blueE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$  | $18$

If Callan hikes $4$ times as many hours, he hikes $4$ times as many kilometers.

|||
-|-|-|-
Hours | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{4}}\rightarrow$ | $4$
Kilometers | $\blueE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{4}}\rightarrow$  | $24$

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Hours, $x$ | Kilometers, $y$ | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ |  $6$ | $(1, 6)$
$3$|  $18$ | $(3, 18)$
$4$ |  $24$ | $(4, 24)$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Hours and the y-axis labeled Kilometers. The points (1, 6), (3, 18), and (4, 24) are plotted.

hints.content:
The completed table

Hours, $x$ | Kilometers, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $6$
$3$| $18$
$4$ |  $24$

And the completed graph

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Hours and the y-axis labeled Kilometers. The points (1, 6), (3, 18), and (4, 24) are plotted.

question.content:
Yuna's favorite type of cheese crackers has  $30$ crackers for each serving.

**Complete the table for the given ratio.** 
  
Servings, $x$ | Crackers, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $30$
$2$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$3$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

**Plot the ordered pairs $(x,y)$ from the table on the following graph.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
The cheese crackers have $\blueE{30}$ crackers for every $\purpleE1$ serving.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

Then we will plot the ratios in the form (servings, crackers).

If Yuna eats $2$ times as many servings, she eats $2$ times as many crackers.

|||
-|-|-|-
Servings | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{2}}\rightarrow$ | $2$
Crackers | $\blueE{30}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{2}}\rightarrow$  | $60$

If Yuna eats $3$ times as many servings, she eats $3$ times as many crackers.

|||
-|-|-|-
Servings | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$
Crackers | $\blueE{30}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$  | $90$

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Servings, $x$ | Crackers, $y$ | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ |  $30$ | $(1,30)$
$2$|  $60$ | $(2, 60)$
$3$ |  $90$ | $(3, 90)$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Servings and the y-axis labeled Crackers. The points (1, 30), (2, 60), and (3, 90) are plotted.

hints.content:
The completed table

Servings, $x$ | Crackers, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $30$
$2$| $60$
$3$ |  $90$

And the completed graph

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Servings and the y-axis labeled Crackers. The points (1, 30), (2, 60), and (3, 90) are plotted.

question.content:
Justin's rice ball recipe uses $100$ grams of rice to make $1$ rice ball.

**Complete the table for the given ratio.** 
  
Rice balls, $x$ | Rice ($\text{g}$), $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ |  $100$
$2$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$4$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

**Plot the ordered pairs $(x,y)$ from the table on the following graph.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

options.labelText: grams of rice for 2 rice balls
grams of rice for 4 rice balls

hints.content:
Justin's rice ball recipe uses $100$ grams of rice to make $1$ rice ball.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

Then we will plot the ratios in the form (rice balls, grams of rice).

If Justin makes $2$ times as many rice balls, he needs $2$ times as much rice.

|||
-|-|-|-
Rice balls | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{2}}\rightarrow$ | $2$
Rice $(\text{g})$ | $\blueE{100}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{2}}\rightarrow$  | $200$

If Justin makes $4$ times as many rice balls, he needs $4$ times as much rice.

|||
-|-|-|-
Rice balls | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{4}}\rightarrow$ | $4$
Rice $(\text{g})$ | $\blueE{100}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{4}}\rightarrow$  | $400$

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Rice balls, $x$ | Rice ($\text{g}$), $y$  | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ | $100$ | $(1, 100)$
$2$| $200$ | $(2, 200)$
$4$ |  $400$ | $(4, 400)$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Rice balls and the y-axis labeled Rice, grams. The points (1, 100), (2, 200), and (4, 400) are plotted.

hints.content:
The completed table

Rice balls, $x$ | Rice ($\text{g}$), $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$1$ | $100$
$2$| $200$
$4$ |  $400$

And the completed graph

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Rice balls and the y-axis labeled Rice, grams. The points (1, 100), (2, 200), and (4, 400) are plotted.

question.content:
For every $15$ campers at a summer camp there is $1$ counselor.

**Complete the table for the given ratio.** 
  
Campers, $x$ | Counselors, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$15$ |  $1$
$30$| [[☃ numeric-input 3]]
$45$ |  [[☃ numeric-input 5]]

**Plot the ordered pairs $(x,y)$ from the table on the following graph.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
There are $\blueE{15}$ campers for every $\purpleD1$ counselor.

The values in the table represent ratios that are equivalent to this rate.

Then we will plot the ratios in the form (campers, counselors).

If the camp has $2$ times as many campers, they need $2$ times as many counselors.

|||
-|-|-|-
Campers | $\blueE{15}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{2}}\rightarrow$ | $30$
Counselors | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{2}}\rightarrow$  | $2$

If the camp has $3$ times as many campers, they need $3$ times as many counselors.

|||
-|-|-|-
Campers | $\blueE{15}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$ | $45$
Counselors | $\purpleD{1}$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{3}}\rightarrow$  | $3$

Now we can graph each ratio as an ordered pair in the form $(x,y)$.   

Campers, $x$ | Counselors, $y$ | Ordered pair $(x,y)$
:-: | :-: | :-:
$15$ |  $1$ | $(15, 1)$
$30$|  $2$ | $(30, 2)$
$45$ |  $3$ | $(45, 3)$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Campers and the y-axis labeled Counselors. The points (15, 1), (30, 2), and (45, 3) are plotted.

hints.content:
The completed table

Campers, $x$ | Counselors, $y$ 
:-: | :-: 
$15$ |  $1$
$30$| $2$
$45$ |  $3$


And the completed graph

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Campers and the y-axis labeled Counselors. The points (15, 1), (30, 2), and (45, 3) are plotted.

question.content:
Jaquan washes cars for his neighbors on the weekends. Jaquan uses the same amount of water for each car he washes.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how much water Jaquan uses for $2$, $5$, and $8$ cars.

[[☃ image 1]]

**How much water does Jaquan use for $6$ cars?** 

[[☃ numeric-input 12]] $\text{L}$

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Cars and the y-axis labeled Water, liters. The grid has points plotted at (2, 24), (5, 60), and (8, 96).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of cars}}$ Jaquan washes to the $\goldE{\text{amount of water}}$ Jaquan uses.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{24})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{24}$ and means that for every $\blueE2$ cars Jaquan washes, he uses $\goldE{24\,\text{L}}$ of water.

The points are all on a straight line through the origin because they represent equivalent ratios.

To find out how much water Jaquan uses for washing $6$ cars, we can multiply both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{24}$ by $3$.

If Jaquan washes $3$ times as many cars, he uses $3$ times as much water.

|||
-|-|-|-
Cars | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $6$
Water ($\text{L}$) | $\goldE{24}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $72$

We can plot the ratio $(6, 72)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Cars and the y-axis labeled Water, liters. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (8, 96). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (2, 24), (5, 60), (6, 72), and (8, 96).

hints.content: Jaquan uses $72\,\text{L}$ of water for washing $6$ cars.

question.content:
Federico read the nutritional information on a package of  gummy bears.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how many gummy bears there are in $2$, $3$, and $5$ servings.

[[☃ image 1]]

**How many gummy bears are there in $4$ servings?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] gummy bears

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Servings and the y-axis labeled Gummy bears. The grid has points plotted at (2, 40), (3, 60), and (5, 100).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of servings}}$ to the $\goldE{\text{number of gummy bears}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{40})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{40}$ and means that for every $\blueE2$ servings, there are $\goldE{40}$ gummy bears.

The points are all on a straight line through the origin because they represent equivalent ratios.

To find out how many gummy bears there are in $4$ servings, we can multiply both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{40}$ by $2$.

If there are $2$ times as many servings, there are also  $2$ times as many gummy bears.

|||
-|-|-|-
Servings | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $4$
Gummy bears | $\goldE{40}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $80$

We can plot the ratio $(4, 80)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Servings and the y-axis labeled Gummy bears. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (5, 100). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (2, 40), (3, 60), (4, 80), and (5, 10).

hints.content: There are  $80$ gummy bears in $4$ servings.

question.content:
Richard went to a zip line park for his birthday.  Richard travels on the zip line at a constant rate.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

The points on the following coordinate plane show how many meters he travelled in $2$, $3$, and $4$ seconds while riding one of the zip lines.

[[☃ image 1]]

**How far does Richard travel on the zip line in $1$ second?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] meters

options.explanation:
Speed on a zip line is not actually constant. Gravity speeds you up when you're going down and slows you when you're going up. Friction slows you down.

For short amounts of time, the speed can be close to constant, so we simplified here.

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Time, seconds and the y-axis labeled Distance, meters. The grid has points plotted at (2, 18), (3, 27), and (4, 36).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of seconds on the zip line}}$ to the $\goldE{\text{number of meters Richard traveled}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{18})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{18}$ and means that for every $\blueE2$ seconds, Richard travels  $\goldE{18}$ meters.

The points are all on a straight line through the origin because they represent equivalent ratios.

To find out how far Richard travels in $1$ second, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{18}$ by $2$.

If we divide the number of seconds traveled by $2$, we also need to divide the number of meters traveled by $2$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Seconds | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Distance (meters) | $\goldE{18}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $9$

We can plot the ratio $(1, 9)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Time, seconds and the y-axis labeled Distance, meters. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (4, 36). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (1, 9), (2, 18), (3, 27), and (4, 36).

hints.content: Richard travels $9$ meters in $1$ second on the zip line.

question.content:
A bricklayer is building a wall.  Each layer of the wall has the same number of bricks.

The points on the following coordinate plane show how many bricks he used to make $2$, $3$, and $4$ layers of the wall.

[[☃ image 1]]

**How many bricks are in $1$ layer of the wall?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] bricks

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Layers and the y-axis labeled Bricks. The grid has points plotted at (2, 100), (3, 150), and (4, 200).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of layers}}$ to the $\goldE{\text{number of bricks}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{100})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{100}$ and means that for every $\blueE2$ layers there are   $\goldE{100}$ bricks.

The points are all on a straight line through the origin because they represent equivalent ratios.

To find out how many bricks are in $1$ layer, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{100}$ by $2$.

If  we divide the number of layers by $2$, we also need to divide the number of bricks by $2$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Layers | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Bricks | $\goldE{100}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $50$

We can plot the ratio $(1, 50)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Layers and the y-axis labeled Bricks. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (4, 200). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (1, 50), (2, 100), (3, 150), and (4, 200).

hints.content: There are  $50$ bricks in $1$ layer of the wall.

question.content:
A swimming pool sets a maximum number of swimmers that can be in the pool based on the number of lifeguards on duty.

The points on the following coordinate plane show the maximum number of swimmers that can be in the pool when $2$, $4$, and $5$ lifeguards are on duty.

[[☃ image 1]]

**What is the maximum number of swimmers that can be in the pool with $3$ lifeguards on duty?** 

 [[☃ numeric-input 12]] swimmers

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Lifeguards and the y-axis labeled Swimmers. The grid has points plotted at (2, 80), (4, 160), and (5, 200).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of lifeguards}}$ to the $\goldE{\text{number of swimmers}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{80})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{80}$ and means that for every $\blueE2$ lifeguards there can be $\goldE{80}$ swimmers.

The points are all on a straight line through the origin because they represent equivalent ratios.

To find out how many swimmers can be in the pool for $1$ lifeguard, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{80}$ by $2$.

If we divide the number of lifeguards by $2$ we should also divide  the number of swimmers by $2$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Lifeguards | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Swimmers | $\goldE{80}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $40$

Now that we know the number of swimmers for $1$ lifeguard, we can multiply both parts of the ratio by $3$ to find the number of swimmers for $3$ lifeguards.

||||
-|-|-|-
Lifeguards | $\blueE{2}$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$
Swimmers | $\goldE{80}$ | $40$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $120$

We can plot the ratio $(3, 120)$ on the coordinate plane to see if it is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Lifeguards and the y-axis labeled Swimmers. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (5, 200). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (2, 80), (3, 120), (4, 160), and (5, 200).

hints.content: There can be $120$ swimmers in the pool with  $3$ lifeguards.

question.content:
Nicky shovels snow at a constant rate.

Nicky plots points on the coordinate plane below to show how many scoops of snow they can shovel in different lengths of time.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following ordered pairs could Nicky add to the graph?** 

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Time, minutes and the y-axis labeled Snow, scoops. The grid has points plotted at (3, 45), (4, 60), and (5, 75).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of minutes}}$ Nicky shovels to the $\goldE{\text{number of scoops}}$ of snow.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE3,\goldE{45})$ represents the ratio $\blueE3:\goldE{45}$ and means that every $\blueE3$ minutes Nicky shovels, they shovel $\goldE{45}$ scoops of snow.

Nicky shovels at a constant rate, so each ratio will be equivalent. The graphs of equivalent ratios are all on a straight line through the origin.

## Ordered pair $(1, 10)$:

To find out how much Nicky shovels in $1$ minute, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE3:\goldE{45}$ by $3$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Time (minutes) | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Snow (scoops) | $\goldE{45}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $15$

Nicky shovels $15$ scoops each minute.

When Nicky shovels for $1$ minute, they shovel $15$ scoops, not $10$.

The ratio of $1:10$ is **not** equivalent to $3:45$.

## Ordered pair $(2, 30)$:

|||||
-|-|-|-
Time (minutes) | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $2$
Snow (scoops) | $\goldE{45}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $15$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $30$

Yes, the ratio of $2:30$ is equivalent to $3:45$!

## Ordered pair $(6, 85)$:

|||
-|-|-|-
Time (minutes) | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $6$
Snow (scoops) | $\goldE{45}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $90$

When Nicky shovels for $6$ minutes, they shovel $90$ scoops, not $85$.

The ratio of $6:85$ is **not** equivalent to $3:45$.

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(2, 30)$ is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Time, minutes and the y-axis labeled Snow, scoops. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (5, 75). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (2, 30), (3, 45), (4, 60), and (5, 75). There are 2 points plotted off of the line at (1, 10) and (6, 85).

hints.content: Nicky could add the ordered pair $(2, 30)$ to the graph.

question.content:
Maggie walks at a constant speed. 

Maggie plots points on the coordinate plane below to show amounts of time it takes her to walk certain distances.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following ordered pairs could Maggie add to the graph?** 

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Hours and the y-axis labeled Distance, kilometers. The grid has points plotted at (2, 10), (4, 20), and (5, 25).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of hours}}$ Maggie walks to the $\goldE{\text{number of kilometers}}$ Maggie walks.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{10})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{10}$ and means that every $\blueE2$ hours, Maggie can walk $\goldE{10}$ kilometers.

Maggie walks at a constant rate, so each ratio will be equivalent. The graphs of equivalent ratios are all on a straight line through the origin.

To find out how far Maggie walks in $1$ hour, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{10}$ by $2$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Time ($\text{h}$) | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Distance ($\text{km}$) | $\goldE{10}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $5$

Maggie walks $5$ kilometers per hour.

## Ordered pair $(3, 18)$:

|||||
-|-|-|-
Time ($\text{h}$) | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$
Distance ($\text{km}$) | $\goldE{10}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $5$| $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $15$

When Maggie walks $3$ hours, she walks $15\,\text{km}$, not $18\,\text{km}$.

The ratio of $3:18$ is **not** equivalent to $2:10$.

## Ordered pair $(5, 1)$:

When Maggie walks $5$ hours, she walks $25\,\text{km}$, not $1\,\text{km}$.

The ratio of $5:1$ is **not** equivalent to $5:25$.

## Ordered pair $(6, 30)$:

|||
-|-|-|-
Time ($\text{h}$) | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $6$
Distance ($\text{km}$) | $\goldE{10}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $30$

Yes, the ratio of $6:30$ is equivalent to $2:10$!

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(6, 30)$ is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Hours and the y-axis labeled Distance, kilometers. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (6, 30). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (2, 10), (4, 20), (5, 25), and (6, 30). There are 2 points plotted off of the line at (3, 18) and (5, 1).

hints.content: Maggie could add the ordered pair $(6, 30)$ to the graph.

question.content:
Lucas always follows the same recipe to make salsa. 

Lucas plots points on the coordinate plane below to show how many tomatoes he needs to make different numbers of batches of salsa.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following ordered pairs could Lucas add to the graph?** 

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Batches and the y-axis labeled Tomatoes. The grid has points plotted at (2, 6), (3, 9), and (5, 15).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of batches of salsa}}$  to the $\goldE{\text{number of tomatoes}}$ needed.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE2,\goldE{6})$ represents the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{6}$ and means that every $\blueE2$ batches of salsa, Lucas will need $\goldE{6}$ tomatoes.

Lucas uses the same recipe each time, so each ratio will be equivalent. The graphs of equivalent ratios are all on a straight line through the origin.

To find out how many tomatoes Lucas needs for $1$ batch of salsa, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE2:\goldE{6}$ by $2$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Batches | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Tomatoes | $\goldE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $3$

Lucas needs $3$ tomatoes for each batch of salsa.

We can use this rate to see which ordered pair Lucas can add to his graph.

## Ordered pair $(3, 1)$:

|||||
-|-|-|-
Batches | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\tealE{\times 3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$
Tomatoes | $\goldE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $3$ | $\stackrel{\tealE{\times 3}}\rightarrow$  | $9$

When Lucas makes $3$ batches of salsa, he needs $9$ tomatoes, not $1$ tomato.

The ratio of $3:1$ is **not** equivalent to $2:6$.

## Ordered pair $(4, 12)$:

|||
-|-|-|-
Batches | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\tealE{\times 2}}\rightarrow$ | $4$
Tomatoes | $\goldE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\tealE{\times 2}}\rightarrow$  | $12$

Yes, the ratio of $4:12$ is equivalent to $2:6$!

## Ordered pair $(6, 16)$:

|||
-|-|-|-
Batches | $\blueE{2}$ | $\stackrel{\tealE{\times 3}}\rightarrow$ | $6$
Tomatoes | $\goldE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\tealE{\times 3}}\rightarrow$  | $18$

When Lucas makes $6$ batches of salsa, he needs $18$ tomatoes, not $16$ tomatoes.

The ratio of $6:16$ is **not** equivalent to $2:6$.

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(4, 12)$ is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Batches and the y-axis labeled Tomatoes. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (5, 15). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (2, 6), (3, 9), (4, 12), and (5, 15). There are 2 points plotted off of the line at (3, 1) and (6, 16).

hints.content: Lucas could add the ordered pair $(4, 12)$ to the graph.

question.content:
Sofia rides her bike at a constant speed. 

Sofia plots points on the coordinate plane below to show amounts of time it takes her to bike certain distances.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following ordered pairs could Sofia  add to the graph?** 

[[☃ radio 2]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Time, hours and the y-axis labeled Distance, kilometers. The grid has points plotted at (3, 30), (4, 40), and (5, 50).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the $\blueE{\text{number of hours}}$  Sofia rides her bike to the $\goldE{\text{number of kilometers}}$ Sofia rides.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE3,\goldE{30})$ represents the ratio $\blueE3:\goldE{30}$ and means that every $\blueE3$ hours, Sofia can ride $\goldE{30}$ kilometers.

Sofia rides at a constant speed, so each ratio will be equivalent. The graphs of equivalent ratios are all on a straight line through the origin.

## Ordered pair $(1, 8)$:

To find out how many miles Sofia can ride in $1$ hour, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE3:\goldE{30}$ by $3$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Hours | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Distance ($\text{km}$) | $\goldE{30}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $10$

Sofia can ride $10$ kilometers for each hour.

When Sofia rides $1$ hour, she goes $10\,\text{km}$, not $8\,\text{km}$.

The ratio of $1:8$ is **not** equivalent to $3:30$.

## Ordered pair $(2, 25)$:

|||||
-|-|-|-
Hours | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \tealE{2}}\rightarrow$ | $2$
Distance ($\text{km}$) | $\goldE{30}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $10$ | $\stackrel{\times \tealE{2}}\rightarrow$  | $20$

When Sofia rides $2$ hours, she goes $20\,\text{km}$, not $25\,\text{km}$.

The ratio of $2:25$ is **not** equivalent to $3:30$.

## Ordered pair $(6, 60)$:

|||
-|-|-|-
Hours | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$ | $6$
Distance ($\text{km}$) | $\goldE{30}$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{2}}\rightarrow$  | $60$

Yes, the ratio of $6:60$ is equivalent to $3:30$!

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(6, 60)$ is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Time, hours and the y-axis labeled Distance, kilometers. A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (6, 60). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (3, 30), (4, 40), (5, 50), and (6, 60). There are 2 points plotted off of the line at (1, 8) and (2, 25).

hints.content: Sofia could add the ordered pair $(6, 60)$ to the graph.

question.content:
Briggs is planning to make a batch of homemade play dough for an art project.

Briggs plots points on the coordinate plane below to show the amount of salt he needs for different amounts of water.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following ordered pairs could Briggs add to the graph?** 

[[☃ radio 2]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Water (scoops) and the y-axis labeled Salt (scoops). The grid has points plotted at (5, 2.5), (6, 3), and (8, 4).

hints.content:
Each point on the graph represents a ratio of the number of scoops of $\blueE{\text{water}}$ to the number of scoops of $\goldE{\text{salt}}$.

For example, the point graphed at  $(\blueE6,\goldE{3})$ represents the ratio $\blueE6:\goldE{3}$ and means that every $\blueE6$ scoops of water, Briggs will need $\goldE{3}$ scoops of salt.

Briggs uses the same recipe each time, so each ratio will be equivalent. The graphs of equivalent ratios are all on a straight line through the origin.

## Ordered pair $(1, 1)$:

To find out how many scoops of salt Briggs will need for  $1$ scoop of water, we can divide both numbers in the ratio $\blueE6:\goldE{3}$ by $6$.

|||
-|-|-|-
Water (scoops) | $\blueE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{6}}\rightarrow$ | $1$
Salt (scoops) | $\goldE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{6}}\rightarrow$  | $0.5$

Briggs will need $0.5$ scoops of salt for each scoop of water.

When Briggs uses $1$ scoop of water, he uses $0.5$ scoops, not $1$, of salt.

The ratio of $1:1$ is **not** equivalent to $6:3$.

## Ordered pair $(3.5, 7)$:

|||||
-|-|-|-
Water (scoops) | $\blueE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{6}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{14}}\rightarrow$ | $14$
Salt (scoops) | $\goldE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{6}}\rightarrow$  | $0.5$ | $\stackrel{\times \redE{14}}\rightarrow$  | $7$

When Briggs uses $7$ scoops of salt, he uses $14$ scoops, not $3.5$, of water.

The ratio of $3.5:7$ is **not** equivalent to $6:3$.

## Ordered pair $(9, 4.5)$:

|||||
-|-|-|-
Water (scoops) | $\blueE{6}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{6}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleE{9}}\rightarrow$ | $9$
Salt (scoops) | $\goldE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\div \purpleD{6}}\rightarrow$  | $0.5$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleE{9}}\rightarrow$  | $4.5$

Yes, the ratio of $9:4.5$ is equivalent to $6:3$!

When we plot all three sets of coordinate pairs, we can see that the ratio $(9, 4.5)$ is in line with the other ratios.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid with the x-axis labeled Water (scoops) and the y-axis labeled Salt (scoops). A dotted line passes through the origin and the point (9, 4.5). There are 4 points plotted on the line at (5, 2.5), (6, 3), (8, 4), and (9, 4.5). There are 2 points plotted off of the line at (1, 1) and (3.5, 7).

hints.content: Briggs could add the ordered pair $(9, 4.5)$ to the graph.
